quote: Sell at twenty.
Is that a joke?
Do I look like I'm joking?
Evade.
She has him.
She's down fifty strips.
Not for long.
What makes you so sure?
Jadzia... is playing a very deep   game. Her strategy will become    apparent any moment now.
I see.        You don't have any idea how this    game is played, do you?
No. But I've developed a new    appreciation for it.
Since when?
Since I married a tongo player.        And I am certain of one thing --    Jadzia will defeat that... Ferengi    bartender.
I don't know about that. Quark's    on a roll. In the last month,    he's won two hundred and six    straight games.
Would you care to... make a wager    on the outcome?
I wouldn't want to bet against a    man's wife.
Name your stakes.
A bottle of bloodwine against a    bottle of scotch whiskey.
Done.
A sale at fifty... and I'm buying    at one hundred.
Pretty big talk for a woman who's    lost fifty strips.
Afraid I can't cover my bets?
Perish the thought. I just hate    to kick someone when they're down.         I'll buy at a hundred. And    confront.
Well, if you're going to kick me,    I'm going to have to kick back.
ESH-ta PAR-mach-KAI!!       I like my bloodwine very young and   very sweet.
Is he a friend of yours?
Just a fan.
I'm afraid I'm going to have to   disappoint all your fans.
A Full Consortium.
Two hundred and seven.       Single malt. Preferably something   from the Highlands.
I'll need some time.
Your credit's good.
Two hundred and seven games...
Did you just lose a bet?
It is of no consequence.
Sorry about that.
I would rather lose a bet on you   than win on someone else.
Good response.
Are you still running that drill    tomorrow afternoon?
I was planning to. Why?
I wanted to recalibrate the    external sensors.
We should be done by sixteen    hundred.
I think that'll work.        Oh -- the Sutherland's going to    be here the day after tomorrow and    I wanted to--
What were you saying?
Nothing.
I don't feel like talking anymore.
Kira to Worf.
This is Worf.
Sorry to bother you, Commander,    but I need to see you and Jadzia    in the captain's office immediately.
On our way.
Jadzia.
Mmmm.
Get up.
I'm coming.
HEY!

We don't have a lot of time, so    I'll get right to it. For the    last two months, Starfleet has    been receiving military    intelligence from a Cardassian    operative. That operative has now    sent an emergency signal    indicating that he needs to speak    to someone in a face-to-face    conversation.
In thirteen hours, he'll beam an    encrypted subspace transmission    to these coordinates near the    Badlands.
Who is this operative?

Intelligence told me his name is    Lasaran, but that's all they'd say    about him. They did emphasize --    several times -- that he's very    important to them and we should    get someone to the Badlands as    soon as possible. So with the    Defiant gone, and most of the    runabouts off on exercises with    the Ninth Fleet...
We just volunteered to take a trip    to the Badlands.
'fraid so. The Shenandoah is    prepped and ready to go on landing    pad "A." Good luck.
No.
No?
No. I'm not going to spend two    weeks hiking across Vulcan's Forge    in the middle of their summer.
I thought you'd always wanted to    see the Forge.
See it? Yes. Honeymoon there?    No.
Well... there is a mountain-   climbing expedition on Andor that    caught my attention --
Worf? My love... ?
Let me make this very clear -- I    do not want to spend my honeymoon    climbing, hiking, sweating,    bleeding or suffering in any way.
Then... what do you want?
Room service.
Room service?

Room service. I want to be    pampered. I want a staff to cater    to our every whim. I want to be    embarrassed by the size of our    room. I want a balcony with a    view that makes you want to break    down and cry from the sheer beauty    of it all. And I don't want to    spend one moment of our honeymoon    suffering from anything except    guilt about our complete self-   indulgence.
Risa?
Not this time.
Welcome to Casperia Prime. The    vacation capital of the Horvian    Cluster.
You have been planning this all    along.
Seems fair. You planned the   wedding.
Very well. Room service.
Really?
Really.
That was easy.
Did you want to fight over it?
No. But I wasn't expecting you   to surrender so quickly.
"Surrender?"
Bad word.
Very bad.
Okay.       But I will say that you've been   unusually... accommodating lately.
What's wrong with that?
Nothing. It's just... unexpected.   Are you feeling all right?
I'm a married man. I have to make    certain... adjustments to my    lifestyle.
Adjustments? Worf, you've become    almost... easygoing. I mean,    what's next -- a sense of humor?
I have a sense of humor.         On the Enterprise, I was    considered to be quite amusing.
That must've been one dull ship.
That's a joke. I get it.       It's not funny, but I get it.
I don't know if I can get used to   this "New you." It's kind of    eerie.
Your problem is that you can't    accept change.
I can't accept change?
That's right.
You've got to be kidding. I've    changed bodies six times, Worf.
Yes, but you are still very set    in your ways.
Look who's talking!

I don't have to sleep on the same    side of the bed every night. Or    brush my hair exactly fifty    strokes every night. Or eat the    same breakfast every day. Or read    the last page of a book before the    beginning. Or lift the --
I get the point.         I don't know how you can live with    someone so... monotonous.
It's not easy.
That was a joke.
This is going to be a very, very,    long trip...
Come in.
You're not dressed.
Is it time?

Seventeen hundred on the dot.         The holosuite is ours for the next    three hours and we'll need every    minute of it. Three British    agents have disappeared in West    Berlin. MI Five suspects the    Soviets may be involved, but the    Americans have intercepted -- what    are you doing with a tongo wheel?
I'm brushing up on my game.
You play tongo?
Sure. Well... I used to. That is,    I played a game once, a long time    ago. Against a Ferengi privateer    and a Romulan mercenary...
Fascinating. Anyway, the    Americans have intercepted a    series of messages between    Istanbul and a remote island in    the South Pacific that might--
Let's play one hand.
Miles...
One hand. I need the practice.
Why?
I want to beat Quark.
Good luck.
Luck has nothing to do with it.   Tongo is a game of strategy and   calculated risk. Pull up a chair.
I don't even know the rules.
Here.
All right, let's play.
Shenandoah Log:. Stardate xxxxx.x   We have arrived at the designated   coordinates near the Badlands and   are awaiting the transmission from   Lasaran.
This is it.
A very sophisticated encryption    matrix.
Whoever he is... he's good.
Who are you?
I am Commander Worf, this is    Commander Dax. Starfleet    Intelligence sent us here to    receive your transmission.
A Klingon... why did they have to    send a Klingon... ?
I'm a Trill. Does that make you    feel any better?
Are you trying to be funny?
Not at all.       He's the funny one.

I'll get to that in a moment.    First, I have something that you    want. Badly.        Information about the Founders...    I know how many of them are in the    Alpha Quadrant... where they    are... and what they're doing.
We're listening.
I'm sure you are. But now let's    talk about what I want. I want    out. Now.
You mean defect?
Very well. We will relay your    message to Starfleet Intelligence.    They will arrange to bring you out.

I can't wait for them to make    "arrangements." In fifteen    minutes, I'm supposed to leave    here for the Dominion base on    Soukara. I have a feeling this    may be the last time they let me    leave Cardassia Prime, so I need    to take advantage of the    opportunity.
Soukara is inside Dominion-   controlled space. It will not be    easy to make a rendezvous near    that planet without being detected.

Don't work your brain too hard,    Klingon, I've taken care of    everything.        Three days from now, at exactly    seventeen-thirty hours, local    time, I will leave the base and    walk into the jungle. It'll be    at least two days before they know    I'm missing. All you have to do   is get me off the planet. Now --    there are transporter scramblers    protecting Soukara, so you won't    be able to beam me aboard your    ship. You'll have to land and    then meet me at a rendezvous point    on foot.        I'm sending you all the    information you'll need to avoid    the Dominion sensors on the    ground. Follow my instructions,    meet me at the rendezvous point    and have a ship waiting.
We've got the information.        It looks pretty thorough.
We'll need time to study these    plans.
Haven't you been listening! I    don't have time! Once I leave    here, I won't be able to contact    you again. I need to know if    you're going to be there or not,    and I need to know right now.
We'll be there.
Look at how far I've fallen. I'm    risking my life on the word of a    Klingon. Three days -- don't be    late.
All right. I'll buy at... thirty.    With a sale at thirty-five...
Buy at thirty-five, sell at one-   fifty, and index the margin at ten    percent.
Index the margin... ?
Miles, give it up. This just    isn't your game.
We'll see about that. Evade.
Do you realize that Quark has won    two hundred and seven straight    games of tongo?
So?
So someone has to beat him.
And that someone is you?
Why not?
Well, for one thing you can't play    tongo. Confront.
Damn!
Had enough?
Not by a long shot.
Miles, at this rate you won't be    ready to take on Quark for another    twenty years.
One more.
Why are you so determined to beat    Quark?
It's the challenge.
That's it? The challenge?
That's enough. Why do you think    I became an engineer? It's the    challenge.

What do you think has kept me    kayaking down the same river week    after week for the last seven years?    The challenge. Why do I keep    playing darts against someone with    genetically engineered hand-eye    coordination?
The challenge?
Exactly.        Besides, I need something to keep    my mind off the fact that Keiko's    been gone for six months.
Hold on. Maybe I can't beat Quark.    But you can. You and that    genetically engineered brain of yours.
Me? I just learned to play the game.
Yeah -- in about ten seconds. We    can do it, Julian. we can beat him.
"We?" You're talking about me.
You're good at calculation, but    a little... weak on strategy.    I'll be your coach.
No, thank you.
Think of it as a challenge.
That's your obsession, Miles, not    mine.
Do it for the latinum.
Nice try.
Do it for the satisfaction of    seeing the look on Quark's face    when he loses a game of Tongo to    a lowly "Hew-mon."
Deal the cards.
We're approaching the Soukara    system...
Stand-by to bring us out of    warp... now.
There's an asteroid field directly    ahead.
That's what we want. The Dominion    sensor grid in this system has    three gaps -- and they're all in    that asteroid field.
Want me to slow down?
No. Unless... you think you should?
Not at all.        In fact... I could go faster.
A man after my own heart.
Most impressive.
Nothing that any three-hundred-   year-old pilot couldn't do.
We're being scanned from the    surface.
Did they get a fix on us?
I don't think so.
Good. We've come too long a way    just to get shot down.
If you take the helm, I'll scan    the surface for a landing site.
There's the base.
The rendezvous point...
And the Dominion sensor perimeter.

There's a valley about twenty    kilometers north of the rendezvous    point. It's a long way to go on    foot in the jungle, but I don't    think we can risk taking the ship    any closer to their sensors.
Agreed.
We have less than two days to    reach the rendezvous point...
That's about ten kilometers a    day -- shouldn't be too bad.
Do not underestimate the task    ahead. We still have to penetrate    the sensor grid and avoid the    Dominion patrols...
Find a man in the middle of an    alien jungle, and then walk him    out, without getting caught, I    know. Piece of cake.
Ready?
After you.
Okay... go to twenty-five joules...
Done.
That's it. We're linked.
Here -- check my work.
The Dominion encryption lockouts are...       Bypassed. Our tricorders are...        Linked to their sensor grid. And    our lifesigns are...        Masked. Nicely done.
Thank you.
Of course, that means our    tricorders will be useless from    now on.
There you go again, always looking    for the cloud in the silver lining.
I'm not complaining. I look    forward to walking through the    jungle without a map or any idea    about what lies ahead.
The funny thing is, you probably    are.
This is a Ferengi-only game,    gentlemen.
You let Dax play.
She's an exception -- the only    exception.
Afraid I'll clean you out?
I'm afraid you'll embarrass    yourself and ruin the game for the    rest of us.
I think I can keep up. The    question is, can you keep up with    me?
Don't try to scare me with that    gentically engineered intellect    of yours, doctor.
Tongo is more than just number-   crunching. They have yet to    create the computer that can    master this game.
Then you shouldn't have anything    to worry about.
You realize we're not playing for    drinks. This is a high-stakes game.
We came to play.
Gentlemen?
All right. The buy-in is five    strips, and you're dealing.
Better get off to a fast start.
They won't know what hit them.
Buy at three hundred and sell at    three fifty.
You're a quick study, doctor, I'll    give you that.
You mean quick for a "Hew-mon,"    don't you, Quark?
I would never say something so    distasteful during a game.
You'd wait until it was over.
Of course. Evade.
Dax was a quick study too. She    told me it only took her two weeks    to win her first match -- that's    practically unheard of.
Dax specializes in the unexpected.    I'm still buying at three hundred,    selling at four hundred and I'd    like to index the margin at twenty    percent.
Interesting.         She certainly did the unexpected    when she married Commander Boring.
That's for sure.
When they first started seeing    each other, I thought, "This can't    last -- I give it two months."    I'll buy at four hundred and sell    at five.
I had the same thought... but to    tell you the truth, I only gave    it a month. Confront.
She's a real heartbreaker, that    one.
That she is.

Leverage the buy-in and sell at    five-fifty. You know, you go    through a lot of ups and downs in    my business. There're days when    the profits are down and the    customers are scarce... and you    begin to wonder if you'll ever see    another strip of latinum. But    then Jadzia comes in... and    flashes that smile of hers... and    suddenly things don't seem so bad    after all.
I know exactly what you mean...    exactly.        You know, sometimes she'll walk    past the Infirmary and just wink    at me... and my whole day becomes    a little brighter.
Focus, Julian, focus!
I'll buy that five fifty.    Discount the exchange at ten.
And now she's married.
Married.

Out of reach. I'm converting my    reserves and selling at six    hundred.        And you know what's really sad?    What really keeps me awake at    night? She's out of reach because    we let her go.
I suppose so. But... some things    were just not meant to be.
Julian... are you sure you want    to --
Chief, please. You know the    rules -- no coaching during a    round.

You're probably right.        But on the other hand, what if    that's just a convenient    rationalization? What if deep    down in our heart of hearts we    both know that she's something    unique, something that we may    never see again -- a chance at    true happiness... and we let her    slip through our fingers. What    if fifty years from now we each    look back and say, "What a fool    I was?" Confront.
Doctor?
Hmm?
Confront.
Oh. Sorry.
Full consortium.
Total monopoly.
What?
You seem to be out of money.
Miles?
We're busted.
Thanks for the game. You're    welcome back anytime.
Quark -- wait. Did you really    mean all that? About Dax. How    she might've been my one last    chance for true happiness?
Doctor -- you don't expect me to    show you all my cards do you?
You lost.
What happened to "we?"
"We" weren't mooning over lost    love with a Ferengi who was    holding a total monopoly.
Are you saying all that talk about    Dax was meant to distract me?
Obviously.
I can't believe I let him get to    me...
It's not your fault. Genetically    engineered or not, you're still    "Hew-mon."
I guess...
Come on, Let's go get a drink.
Let's not stand on pride, shall    we? Trills don't like the heat,    and Klingons don't like the cold.    There's no shame in admitting it.
Thank you.
You're welcome. And I hope you're    enjoying your honeymoon. Are you    suffering enough?
Almost.
Something else I can get for you?
More pain, less cold.
I don't know why that's funny...    but it is.
Mating call?
Five hundred meters...        That way.
That didn't take long.
Less than three hundred meters...
Another happy couple.

When I was a boy, my father used    to take my brother and me on    camping trips into the Ural    Mountains. Every night we'd hear    the wolves howling in the    distance. Nikolai was always    afraid of them, but I'd lie there    in my tent for hours... just    listening.        And I remember being seized by the    urge to just... strip off my    clothes and run into the night...    to live in the forest... and    become something... wild.
He's moving off. Must've been    rejected.
She doesn't sound happy.
What? They're getting farther    away, aren't they?
Yes. But that's because something    else is coming.         And it's close.
Jadzia?
Painkillers... please.
Lie still.
I can do that.
I'd like the good news first.
No vital organs were damaged.
The disruptor burst left an anti-   coagulant in your system...
And you can't stop the bleeding.
It looks like I didn't take the    full burst... the hemorrhaging's    not too bad yet. Just keep    pumping me full of painkillers and    we'll be on our way.
Moving could make the bleeding    worse.
Staying here isn't an option.        Someone's going to start looking for   them when they don't check in. I'd    rather take my chances on foot.
Ready?        Ready?
Ready.
Then let's go.
We're still twelve kilometers from    the rendezvous point.
And only twenty hours left. I    guess it's time to stop having so    much fun and pick up the pace, huh?
More plasma? No, thanks. I'm    full.
Your blood pressure has dropped    another twenty percent.
Love that bedside manner. You    should've been a doctor.
Your dressing will need to be changed soon.
I think I'd like a blue chiffon    bandage this time -- maybe some    rhinestones -- you know, something    with a little pizazz.
This is not a joking matter. You    are seriously injured and we have    a great deal of terrain to cover.
Just trying to lighten the mood.
This is not the time nor the place.
What happened to that new Worf?    You know, the one with a sense of    humor?
That was a mistake.
What's that supposed to mean?
It means if I had not been joking    with you, I would not have let the    Jem'Hadar get that close.
So this is all my fault?
No. It is mine. I was trying to    be something I am not.
By letting down my guard -- by    ignoring my duty -- I allowed my    wife to be injured and I put the    entire mission in jeopardy. It    will not happen again.
That's not the way it happened.    Without our tricorders there was    no way to know that --
I do not wish to debate this! We    have a long way to go and very    little time.
Fine. Let's go.
Ready?
Jadzia... ?
Hhhh... hhhh... hypo.
There we go... good as new.
I have to change the dressing.
That's four bandages in two    hours... that has to be some kind    of... record.
Sorry. I forgot the new rules --    nothing funny... we have to be    serious... life and death... we've    got a job to do.
Jadzia. I know you're tired. But    we need to cover at least three    more kilometers before nightfall.    Can you do it?
As long as you have those    painkillers, I'll follow you    through the gates of hell... sir.
Hey... that was almost a smile.
When this mission is over... I'll    smile all you want.
Promise?
Promise.
Then let's finish the mission and    get out of here.
I can stand... just help me... get    my balance...
Or... maybe not.
Let me guess -- things are not    looking up.
There's been another drop in your    blood pressure... and your neural    EDL readings are erratic.
So, doc, what's your prescription?
You need surgery... at a Starbase.
Can I get a second opinion?
Worf... you have to go on without    me. I know that. And it's all    right.
My... duty requires me to... carry    out the mission regardless of...    my personal feelings.
Absolutely. You're a Starfleet    officer. So am I. I understand.
The information Lasaran has    could... potentially be...    invaluable to the war effort...
You don't have to explain    yourself. I'm hurt. You're not.    And there's a job to do.
I'll be back tomorrow night.
Don't worry, I'm not going    anywhere.
We can have you in the stasis    chamber on the Runabout in...       ... forty-five hours.
No problem.
I'll leave you the medkit. Scan    yourself with the tricorder every    half-hour. The plasma hypospray    is set to --
I took basic first aid. I know    what to do.
It's been a good two months,    hasn't it?
Yes...        Jadzia... I want to tell you how    much you've --
Worf. Just kiss me and go.
What's the word?
She's still in surgery. But    Doctor Bashir is hopeful she'll    make a full recovery.
Lasaran's dead. Intelligence    intercepted a transmission saying    he was killed trying to re-enter    the base on Soukara.
Could you have made the rendezvous?
Yes.
But you turned back to save Jadzia?
Yes.
Were you aware that man's    information could have saved    millions of lives?
Yes.
So what happened?
You may not understand...
Try me.

You were at my wedding... you    heard the story of the first two    Klingon hearts... how nothing    could stand against them... and    how they even destroyed the gods    that created them. I've heard    that story ever since I was a    boy...

... but I never understood it --    really understood it -- until I    was standing there in the jungle    with my heart pounding in my    chest... and I found that even I   couldn't stand against my own    heart. I had to go back... and    it didn't matter what Starfleet    thought or what the consequences    were. She was my wife and I    couldn't leave her.

As your captain, it's my duty to    tell you that you made the wrong    choice. I don't think Starfleet    will file any formal charges --    even a secret court-martial would    run the risk of revealing too much    about their intelligence    operations.
But this will go in your service    record... and to be completely    honest, you should know that    they'll probably never give you    a command of your own after this.
I understand.
I've also issued new orders    stating that you and Jadzia are    not to be assigned to missions on    your own ever again.
One last thing: as a man who had    a wife... I can tell you that if    it had been Jennifer lying in that    clearing... I don't think I    could've left her either.
Hey... I know you...
We've met.
You're joking again... that must    be a good sign. Did you... make    the rendezvous?
No.        I couldn't leave you there. Not    for Lasaran or the mission or    anything else.
Lasaran?
Dead.
Are you in trouble?
I've been in trouble before.
I'm so sorry. I should've kept    going...
You have nothing to be sorry about.
I know how much your career means    to you...
You come first. Before my career,    my duty -- before everything. I    don't regret what I did. And I'd    do it again.
I don't know what to say.
You could say, "Thank you for    saving my life."
Thank you for saving my life.
And you could say, "I'd do the    same for you, Worf."
Well... I'll have to think about    that one... my career is very    important to me, you know.
And you could say that you love me.
I love you.
And I love you.
